description: From Middle English chaser, chacer, chasour, borrowed from Old French chaceür, chaceor, from chacier (“to chase, hunt”); later senses from or influenced by chase (“pursue”) +‎ -er. Doublet of chasseur.

entries.meaning: A person or thing (ship, plane, car, etc.) that chases. [from 14th c.]
A horse: (originally) a horse used for hunting; (now) a horse trained for steeplechasing, a steeplechaser. [from 14th c.]
examples: "[I]t looked like The Fellow was the best steeplechaser in many years. He'd earned the best speed rating I'd ever given a chaser."

entries.meaning: A drink consumed after another of a different kind.
(logging, obsolete) Someone who follows logs out of the forest in order to signal a yarder engineer to stop them if they become fouled (also called a frogger).
examples: "...on one end known as a Bardon choker hook, to facilitate making a loop. It stays tight and makes it unnecessary for the "chaser" or "choker setter" to follow the "turn" to the landing as might have to be done if tongs are used"

entries.meaning: (logging) One who unhooks chokers from the logs at the landing.
examples: "The rigging slinger hooks the chokers to the main line, the chaser unhooks them at the spar tree."

entries.meaning: (slang, historical) A piece of music, etc. played after a performance while the audience leaves.
examples: After the final curtain the orchestra played a "chaser" which was music played while the audience members not remaining for the after-show concert left the theatre.

entries.meaning: One of a series of adjacent light bulbs that cycle on and off to give the illusion of movement.
A long piece of flexible wire used to draw an electrical cable through a wall cavity.
Synonym of prison chaser (“person who guards military prisoners”)

definitionGroups.group: (slang) A person who seeks out sexual partners with a particular quality:

entries.meaning: (slang) A person who seeks partners with HIV in order to become infected.
In the sport of Quidditch or Muggle quidditch, a player responsible for passing the quaffle and scoring goals with it.
Someone who chases (decorates) metal; a person who decorates metal by engraving or embossing. [from 18th c.]
examples: "Mr B., heraldic chaser, says there are several processes in making heraldy plates, sketching, engraving, embossing, chasing and burnishing."

"H. & C., manufacturers of cloth and gilt buttons, say it requires some weeks to learn to chase the gilt buttons, which are done with small metal tools and a hammer. Chasers are paid by the piece, working ten hours a day, and some can earn $1 a day."

entries.meaning: A tool used for cleaning out screw threads, either as an integral part of a tap or die to remove waste material produced by the cutting tool, or as a separate tool to repair damaged threads. [from 19th c.]
examples: "In Fig. i is shown one of the chasers in the position which it occupies in cutting a thread."
